posts.post_content:
@InfernoTowel: given that Progenitus goes back into your library, he manages to escape the full force of God's wrath and can potentially come back to fight another day. =P  
  
In any case, a great card, and for only 4 mana it definitely deserves 5 stars. Early game it can swing the momentum in your favour if you're looking at some solid cards in your hand, mid game it can reset the creature part of the battlefield if things aren't looking too good, and late game if you have enough mana it can clear the field and let you follow up with a powerful creature spell like Conqueror's Pledge - if you manage to have a Coat of Arms out too, it'd be hard to imagine your opponent getting enough blockers to survive the 30 points of damage that would be coming their way next turn.
posts.html:

In any case, a great card, and for only 4 mana it definitely deserves 5 stars. Early game it can swing the momentum in your favour if you're looking at some solid cards in your hand, mid game it can reset the creature part of the battlefield if things aren't looking too good, and late game if you have enough mana it can clear the field and let you follow up with a powerful creature spell like Conqueror's Pledge - if you manage to have a Coat of Arms out too, it'd be hard to imagine your opponent getting enough blockers to survive the 30 points of damage that would be coming their way next turn.

posts.post_content:
Wrath of Gods giant white nut.
  
Any card that appears 4 times in every campionship deck ever should be good right?

posts.post_content: @ Dingo777, Progenitus can't be targeted by anything, but Wrath of God doesn't have a target, it just blows everything up. I like it but i would say, just strictly because of its flavor text, Day of Judgement> WoG. I would rather risk having my opponents regen but have a Sorin Markov quotation than wipe the field clear and not have Sorin. It's one of the only two cards with a quotation from him on it so that makes it pretty awesome.

posts.post_content:
A card truly fit to bear the title of our Lord, this is almost perfection in cardboard form. [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God) will never truly die. As long as Magic is played, so will [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God).   
  
Unless Wizards do the unthinkable, and print something strictly better than [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God). Let it be known that that day is the day that power creep will finally destroy Magic.
posts.html:
A card truly fit to bear the title of our Lord, this is almost perfection in cardboard form. Wrath of God will never truly die. As long as Magic is played, so will Wrath of God.

Unless Wizards do the unthinkable, and print something strictly better than Wrath of God. Let it be known that that day is the day that power creep will finally destroy Magic.
